block.p: A GOVERNMENT report on Tuesday about the current account deficit for the second quarter is likely to prompt new concerns about the value of the dollar.

The current account measures the country's balance of trade in goods and services with the rest of the world. It is expected to be a deficit of $158 billion for the second quarter, raising the total for the first six months of the year to about $303 billion, more than 11 percent higher than the deficit for the first six months of 2003.

The current account measures the country's balance of trade in goods and services with the rest of the world. It is expected to be a deficit of $158 billion for the second quarter, raising the total for the first six months of the year to about $303 billion, more than 11 percent higher than the deficit for the first six months of 2003.
At that rate, the deficit could top $600 billion for the year, swamping the record of $531 billion set last year.
Currency strategists worry that the deficit must be covered by money from abroad, and that if this flow slows down, interest rates may go higher and the dollar lower.

Despite the growth in the deficit, the dollar has been relatively stable for the last several months; it is actually up for the year against both the euro and the Japanese yen -- maybe because the foreign funds flow into the United States has been speeding up, not slowing down.

In the first six months of the year, foreigners bought a net $440.5 billion of American stocks and bonds, up from $326.3 billion in the first six months of 2003, according to Treasury Department figures adjusted to fully reflect the net inflow of foreign money.
That flow is well ahead of the size of the current account deficit. But one major concern is that a large part of this money is coming from foreign central banks, especially those in China and Japan.

So far this year, official foreign institutions, which include central banks, have bought 30 percent, or $150.6 billion, of the $504.3 billion that foreigners spent on United States Treasury, agency and corporate bonds, before special adjustments. That is up from $56.1 billion, or 15.6 percent, in the first six months of 2003.

Just going back to the 2003 pace would lower the adjusted inflow to about $370 billion, so a change in the appetite of other foreign investors could quickly make the current account deficit very troubling.

DATA RUSH -- This week's data will provide a broad measure of the economy's well-being. A report on Tuesday on August retail sales is expected to show a decline of 0.1 percent, according to Bloomberg News, but that is mostly because of a slowdown in auto sales. Retail sales, excluding autos, are expected to rise 0.2 percent, matching the July gain.

Industrial production for August, to be reported Wednesday, is expected to show a jump of 0.5 percent, after a 0.4 percent climb in July. The Consumer Price Index for August, due on Thursday, is predicted to rise 0.2 percent, after a 0.1 percent decline in July.
